title: RL31919
content: According to the Federal Trade Commission, identity theft is the most common complaint from consumers in all 50 states, accounting for over 35% of total complaints received for calendar years 2004-2006. In 2006, out of 674,354 complaints, 36% were related to identity theft. Victims may experience credit card fraud, phone or utilities fraud, bank fraud, employment-related fraud, government documents or benefits fraud, loan fraud, and other types of identity theft fraud. This can result in damaged credit records, unauthorized charges on credit cards, unauthorized withdrawals from bank accounts, and the need to change personal information like telephone numbers and social security numbers. The report provides an overview of federal laws to assist victims of identity theft in purging inaccurate information from credit records and removing unauthorized charges from credit accounts. The Identity Theft Assumption Deterrence Act prohibits fraud in connection with identification documents, including cases of consumer identity theft. Impostors could be prosecuted under this statute for assuming another person's identity through fraudulent means. The federal statute prohibits fraud related to identification documents, including consumer identity theft. Offenses include producing or possessing stolen identification documents, transferring or using another person's identification without lawful authority. Punishments vary depending on the specific offense, with fines or imprisonment up to 15 years possible. The punishment for offenses involving fraud related to identification documents varies depending on the specific offense and the type of document involved. Penalties range from fines or imprisonment up to 15 years for using another person's identification with intent to commit unlawful activity. Offenses related to drug trafficking or terrorism can result in longer prison terms, up to twenty-five years. The Identity Theft Penalty Enhancement Act of 2004 defines and establishes penalties for aggravated identity theft. The Identity Theft Penalty Enhancement Act of 2004 amends Title 18 of the United States Code to define and establish penalties for aggravated identity theft. Aggravated identity theft occurs when a person knowingly uses another person's identification during certain felonies, with penalties including imprisonment of two years and additional terms for terrorism offenses. The act also directs the United States Sentencing Commission to review and amend guidelines for punishing identity theft offenses. Additionally, appropriations are authorized for the investigation and prosecution of identity theft. The Identity Theft Penalty Enhancement Act of 2004 amended Title 18 of the United States Code to define and establish penalties for aggravated identity theft, including imprisonment for certain felonies. The act also authorized appropriations for the investigation and prosecution of identity theft cases. The Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA) provides assistance to victims by allowing them to have negative information resulting from unauthorized charges or accounts removed from their credit files. The FCRA outlines consumer rights regarding credit reports, permissible uses, and disclosure requirements. The FCRA outlines consumer rights in relation to credit reports, including permissible uses and disclosure requirements. It imposes a duty on consumer reporting agencies to ensure accuracy of reported information. Consumers can file suit for violations, such as inaccurate information disclosure. The FACT Act, signed in 2003, includes amendments to the FCRA. The FACT Act, signed in 2003, includes amendments to the Fair Credit Reporting Act aimed at preventing identity theft and assisting victims. New provisions require credit card issuers to follow certain procedures to prevent fraud, such as truncating credit card numbers on receipts and social security numbers on credit reports. Victims of identity theft have specific rights under the Act, including a time limit to file a lawsuit for violations. The new provisions under the FACT Act include truncating credit card account numbers on receipts and social security numbers on credit reports. Consumers can request fraud alerts to be placed in their files for 90 days, with an option to extend up to seven years. Victims of identity theft can also block information resulting from the crime on their credit reports. Victims of identity theft can request information to be blocked from their credit reports and can also request information about the alleged crime. Businesses must provide transaction records upon request and verification of the victim's identity. The Fair Credit Billing Act (FCBA) allows consumers to dispute unauthorized charges and billing errors in credit transactions. Consumers can request an explanation and proof of charges made by impostors and have unauthorized charges removed from their accounts. The FCBA aims to protect consumers from inaccurate credit billing practices and provides a procedure for resolving billing errors. Victims of identity theft can request transaction records to be provided to them or law enforcement agencies investigating the theft. The Fair Credit Billing Act (FCBA) allows consumers to dispute unauthorized charges and billing errors in credit transactions. Consumers can request an explanation and proof of charges and file a claim with the creditor to resolve billing errors. The Electronic Fund Transfer Act provides a mechanism for challenging unauthorized transactions and having accounts recredited in case of errors. It establishes rights, liabilities, and responsibilities in electronic fund transfer systems. The Electronic Fund Transfer Act (EFTA) establishes rights, liabilities, and responsibilities in electronic fund transfer systems. It limits a consumer's liability for unauthorized transfers and requires financial institutions to provide documentation of all electronic fund transfers initiated by the consumer. If an error is reported within 60 days, the financial institution must investigate and rectify the issue. The Electronic Fund Transfer Act (EFTA) requires financial institutions to investigate and correct errors reported by consumers within 60 days. If an error is identified, the institution must rectify it within one day and may provisionally recredit the consumer's account. The President's Identity Theft Task Force recommended a plan to crack down on identity theft by harnessing government resources, protecting personal information, educating consumers, and increasing data security. The plan focuses on preventing identity theft, assisting victims, and deterring criminals through aggressive prosecution. The President's Identity Theft Task Force recommended amendments to federal criminal statutes to prosecute identity theft-related offenses more effectively, including prosecuting identity thieves who target corporations, adding new crimes to the list of offenses, penalizing creators of malicious software, and enhancing sentences for identity thieves affecting multiple victims. The Department of Homeland Security published the final rule for State-issued driver's licenses and identification cards to comply with the REAL ID Act of 2005, setting standards for issuing secure identification documents. States have until December 31, 2009, to meet the security benchmarks for their credentials and processes. The final rule for State-issued driver's licenses and identification cards to comply with the REAL ID Act of 2005 sets security standards. States have until December 31, 2009, to meet benchmarks, with possible extensions. Compliance deadline for REAL ID-compliant cards is December 1, 2014, for those born after December 1, 1964, and December 1, 2017, for those born on or before. Effective March 31, 2008.
